messages.text:
I attended a hands on, over the shoulder class in the Clinical Mastery Series: Mastering Implant Success. Dr Lee Ann Brady and Dr David Barget presented information from the treatment planning to actual extraction and immediate placement of anterior implants on live patients yesterday. Combining both restorative and surgery into one course is helpful to understand implant success from each perspective. I am looking forward to Day 2!
Dr Lee Ann Brady
Dr John Nosti, attendee
Dr Barget placing immediate implant
On the second day of the Clinical Mastery over-the-shoulder hands on implant class, we talked about custom provisionals and transferring the final contours of the matured gingiva to the lab. We were able to make our own in-office provisional on an anterior implant model of the actual patient that Dr Brady was seeing in the adjacent operatory.Dr Lee BradyDr Brady and meHaving the periodontist, restorative dentist and lab all present at this course enabled us to ask questions at all stages of the implant process. The lectures were given with clear explanations of each procedure and we were shown both successes and failures. There were multiple patients that we observed either over-the-shoulder or with the live video streaming on flat screens. From an implant restorative dentist's perspective, I have a whole new respect for the challenges the surgeon faces in the placement of the implant and the need for good communication between the periodontist, the lab and me.No matter whether you have been placing implants for years or only do implant restorative in your practice, you will learn many pearls from attending this Clinical Mastery Class. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ 5 stars
Betty are you placing implants? Do you use a CBCT? Which brand? Are you using a surgical guide stint made from data from a CBCT? Is Lee Ann?

I am not placing implants, Howard.  I just restore them after my periodontist, Dr. Ralph Wilson places them.  
Dr. Lee Brady also restores them after her surgeon, which often happens to be Dr. Barget, places them.
There were a number of attendees that placed their own implants.  Dr. Barget discussed in depth where to place the implants and how to gauge where the recession and bone loss would occur ahead of time.  He does a CT graft on every anterior implant and demonstrated that on live patients.  He also showed what to do if the plan was for an immediate placement and there was no stability once it was attempted.  For those who place their own implants, a class like this where you can troubleshoot your placement technique by watching while someone else does theirs, would be invaluable in my opinion.

conversion.ai_response:
{
"role": "user",
"content": "What can you tell me about the Clinical Mastery Series Implant Course? What are the key takeaways and benefits of attending this course?"
},
{
"role": "assistant",
"content": "The Clinical Mastery Series Implant Course is a comprehensive hands-on experience that covers the entire implant process from treatment planning to actual extraction and immediate placement of anterior implants on live patients. The course combines both restorative and surgical perspectives, which helps attendees understand implant success from different angles.

Key takeaways include:

1. Clear explanations of each procedure, with lectures covering successes and failures.
2. Observing multiple patients, either over-the-shoulder or with live video streaming on flat screens.
3. Understanding the challenges that surgeons face in implant placement and the importance of good communication between the periodontist, restorative dentist, and lab.
4. Learning about custom provisionals and transferring the final contours of the matured gingiva to the lab.
5. Making in-office provisionals on an anterior implant model.
6. Insight into the implant restorative dentist's perspective and the unique challenges they face.

The course is valuable for both experienced implant professionals and those who only do implant restorative work in their practice. Attendees can learn many pearls and troubleshoot their placement techniques by watching others perform implant procedures."
}
]

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
What can you tell me about the Clinical Mastery Series Implant Course? What are the key takeaways and benefits of attending this course?

The Clinical Mastery Series Implant Course is a comprehensive hands-on experience that covers the entire implant process from treatment planning to actual extraction and immediate placement of anterior implants on live patients. The course combines both restorative and surgical perspectives, which helps attendees understand implant success from different angles.

Key takeaways include:

1. Clear explanations of each procedure, with lectures covering successes and failures.
2. Observing multiple patients, either over-the-shoulder or with live video streaming on flat screens.
3. Understanding the challenges that surgeons face in implant placement and the importance of good communication between the periodontist, restorative dentist, and lab.
4. Learning about custom provisionals and transferring the final contours of the matured gingiva to the lab.
5. Making in-office provisionals on an anterior implant model.
6. Insight into the implant restorative dentist's perspective and the unique challenges they face.

The course is valuable for both experienced implant professionals and those who only do implant restorative work in their practice. Attendees can learn many pearls and troubleshoot their placement techniques by watching others perform implant procedures.

[Tag: CE Comments / Suggestions / Events]

messages.text:
The math has to work for you.
If you're producing $1mill on your own with 55-60% overhead, you're clearing about $450k take home.
Now comes a partner that buys in at 50%. Without crazy insane growth with an influx of a million new patients for him to see, he will feed off your current patients and a few new patients here and there. In other words, he will not likely contribute much tot he overall gross number. Lets say he produces an additional $200k his first year. The grand total for office production is now $1.2mill. With 55-60% overhead, the net income is $540k. You will have to split the $540 k in half with your new partner. Your new income is now $270k. You just got demoted. I would not want a huge cut in my take home.
The best way to bring in a partner is to start him as an associate for 2-3 years with a goal of growing your practice and hopefully doubling your gross production. That take a ton of work. Many can't do it in 2-3 years.
On the other hand if youre practice is already producing crazy number like $2-2.5 million then a cut in pay won't be as substantial.

For those who do not take medicaid, how long does it take to build the doctor days from adding an associate from PT to FT? 2-3 years? 
Currently at an office FT with zero advertising (absolutely not sure why), take a majority of insurance plans and in an affluent area. The area is relatively competitive and averaging between 30-100 NP a month, typically around 50. Obviously need more NP, as the current operative/hygiene schedule is extremely sparse... or is this an opportunity that has dried up once the minimum is gone?
It's a dream office, the owner if fantastic and she'd be an awesome partner. Staff is amazing too, but how much time does one put into a gig? Not a fan of riding a gravy train.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
As a pedodontist with a partner, how long does it take to build the doctor days from adding an associate from PT to FT? 2-3 years?

For those who do not take Medicaid, it can take 2-3 years to build the doctor days from adding an associate from PT to FT. This is dependent on factors such as the practice's patient base, the area's competitiveness, and the doctor's marketing strategies.

In your case, you're currently working full-time in an office that takes a majority of insurance plans, is in an affluent area, and has a fantastic owner. The staff is amazing, but the operative/hygiene schedule is sparse. While it may seem like an opportunity that has dried up once the minimum is gone, it can be a chance to grow the practice by attracting more new patients.

Keep in mind that building a successful partnership requires a significant investment of time and effort. Consider your goals and the potential return on investment before making a decision.

[Tag: Pediatric Dentistry]

messages.text: Hello,  I am in debate over  two IV sedation CE classes:  USC (Malamed/Reed) or Medical College of Georgia.  If you had the choice which would you prefer and are there other ones that are the same or better?  Thank you for your time and effort!!-Justin

Justin, at a personal level I would recommend USC.  I have done it twice, the first time about 30 years ago the first time Stan offered it and two years ago when I decided to get my IV permit back after not grandfathering in when the permitting process changed.  Course is well run and  and you will get the  necessary experience and exposure.  The only problem is time and expense but that is true for all the courses.  I have not had personal experience with the Georgia course but I do know it comes higly rated by its participants.  Obviously the CA course is also closer for you from a travel matter.  If you decide to do the USC course let me know and I can give you some advice on what to bring etc.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.

I'm trying to decide between two IV sedation CE classes: USC (Malamed/Reed) or Medical College of Georgia. Can you recommend one and suggest any other options that are similar or better? Thank you for your time and effort!

Hi Justin, I recommend the USC course based on personal experience. I have taken it twice, once 30 years ago and more recently when I decided to get my IV permit back. The course is well-run and provides necessary experience and exposure.

While I don't have personal experience with the Georgia course, it comes highly rated by its participants. Choosing the USC course may be more convenient for you since it's closer to your location.

If you decide to take the USC course, I can offer some advice on what to bring and other helpful tips. Good luck with your decision!

[Tag: Anesthesiology]

messages.text: It's all in how you communicate. The manager should also have a short call list. If cancels, no shows and/or empty slots are in a normal range then don't sweat it. If they are on the high side, that's another story.

Thanks chubbs. That was my hunch. Just nice to be validated. Sometimes feels like in the crazy one ...so thank you. 
Nat: I like the idea about short notice call list thanks!

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
What is the best way to fill same day openings?

Filling same day openings is all about communication. The manager should maintain a short call list. If cancels, no shows, and/or empty slots are in a normal range, there's no need to worry. However, if they are on the high side, that's a different story.

A good idea is to have a short notice call list. This way, when there are openings, you can quickly reach out to those who have signed up for the list and fill the slots.

[Tag: Front Office Discussion]

chat.topic: Tissue grafting before or after ortho

messages.text: I am just wondering if anyone has experience with patients having tissue grafting done prior to orthodontic treatment?We recently referred a patient to the orthodontist for a consultation. They recommended that she have a tissue graft placed on tooth #11 which has approx. 6 mm of recession prior to ortho. My concern is that the graft may not respond well to orthodontic movement. Is it normal to graft prior to braces?
Yup.  Fix it now.  Getting a good result with 6mm recession is hard enough.  Don't need to risk it worsening.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.

I am just wondering if anyone has experience with patients having tissue grafting done prior to orthodontic treatment? We recently referred a patient to the orthodontist for a consultation. They recommended that she have a tissue graft placed on tooth #11 which has approx. 6 mm of recession prior to ortho. My concern is that the graft may not respond well to orthodontic movement. Is it normal to graft prior to braces?

Yes, it is common to perform tissue grafting before orthodontic treatment. Addressing the 6mm recession before starting braces is a good approach.

## Fixing the Recession

Fixing a significant recession, like the 6mm recession mentioned, is challenging enough. Performing the grafting before braces ensures that the graft has a better chance to respond well without the risk of worsening during the orthodontic treatment.

[Tag: Orthodontics]

messages.text: From the image it does not appear that these stains are intrinsic caused by internal bleeding of the pulp. There is no discoloration at the cervical.  You may indeed get full satisfaction from bleaching with a custom tray delivered system.  I recommend Ultradent Opalesence.

Not from trauma. These stains are within the enamel, no dentin. Sometimes you can easily just polish these off. Maybe not perfectly, but an improvement. At age 26, I'd hate to be too aggressive.
Agree with the others that you should start conservative because if he is satisfied, he can stop at any point in the process.
1-new composite, polish and blend in. Like it? If so, done.
2-home bleaching. Keep in mind that everything whitens, so he might still have some spots, but over all better. Like it? Done.
3-prep for veneers. But at his age, never done.

Start with a conservative approach, as you can stop the process at any point if the patient is satisfied.

#### 1. New Composite

- If the patient likes the result, the process can be stopped here.

#### 2. Home Bleaching

- Keep in mind that everything whitens, so there might still be some spots, but overall better.
- If the patient likes the result, the process can be stopped here.

### Advanced Treatment

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
I have a case of a discolored tooth 1121. What could be the cause and how can I treat it?

## Possible Causes and Treatment

Based on the image, it does not appear that the stains are intrinsic, caused by internal bleeding of the pulp. The stains are within the enamel, and you may not need to be too aggressive.

### Conservative Approach

Start with a conservative approach, as you can stop the process at any point if the patient is satisfied.

#### 1. New Composite

- Polish and blend in the new composite.
- If the patient likes the result, the process can be stopped here.

#### 2. Home Bleaching

- Consider home bleaching using a custom tray delivered system.
- Keep in mind that everything whitens, so there might still be some spots, but overall better.
- If the patient likes the result, the process can be stopped here.

### Advanced Treatment

#### 3. Prep for Veneers

- Prep for veneers, but this is typically not recommended for patients at the age of 26, as it is a more aggressive approach.

[Tag: Cosmetic Dentistry]

chat.topic: IDEAS FOR A MUSCLE ENGRAMING PATIENT

messages.text: Help,I have a 52 year old male patient who, after 15 years as a patient, presented for recall with an anterior 2-3mm open bite. Only the second molars were in occlusion.  The patient was unaware of the change.  A px showed no signs of joint degeneration and the patient was asymptomatic.  He was referred to ortho for eval.  Ortho sent him for a MRI which came back WNL.  Ortho noted what they thought to be an enlarged tongue.  He also suffered from chronic persistent erosive lichen planus.  Ortho sent him to an ENT who ordered a CT scan which also came back WNL.  Six weeks later he returned to my office with a progression of the change with only 2 and 31 in occlusion and the anterior opening now at 4-5mm.  Additional questioning revealed that he had been using a CPAP for his apnea for the last 18 months.I believe this is a muscle engraming phenomena in reverse from what is normally observed.  Usually I would fabricate a Kois type deprogramer.  However, considering the nature of the disclussion, I'm not sure if it would help.  I do not have, and have been unable find anyone my area that has, a TENS unit.  I also have a gut feeling that the CPAP/apnea has a role.  At a minimum the disclusion and posterior posturing of the jaw is complicating and worsening the apnea.  I have considered making a TAP apnea appliance to try and slowly bring the mandible forward, but this would be an expensive experiment and I don't feel comfortable treating without a clear diagnosis or etiology.Any thoughts would be welcomeTracy Oliver DDS

Interesting concern here, but in my mind, you have to start with the apnea treatment, and make sure that nothing is done that might compromise his airway and sleep disordered breathing. If he is dead, that open bite won't be much of a problem!Sometimes, wearing an oral appliance- TAP or Somnomed will make wearing the CPAP easier, and if he is having to ramp the pressure on the CPAP pretty high, you might take a look at that.But just like the anterior open bites we sometimes see with NTI's, it might be more of a case of "revealing" an open bite that had been hidden, more than causing it.Rick

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.

I have a patient with an anterior 2-3mm open bite, which has progressed to 4-5mm over 15 years. The patient is unaware of the change and has been using a CPAP for the last 18 months. I suspect a muscle engramming phenomena in reverse, but I'm not sure if fabricating a Kois type deprogrammer would help. I don't have access to a TENS unit and am considering a TAP apnea appliance. Any thoughts?

## Addressing the Apnea
First, it is essential to address the apnea treatment. Make sure that nothing is done that might compromise the patient's airway and sleep-disordered breathing. If the patient is dead, the open bite won't be much of a problem.

## Oral Appliance and CPAP
Wearing an oral appliance, such as a TAP or Somnomed, may make wearing the CPAP easier. If the patient has to ramp the pressure on the CPAP pretty high, you might consider looking into that.

## Revealing the Open Bite
The open bite might be more of a case of 'revealing' an open bite that had been hidden, rather than causing it. This is similar to anterior open bites sometimes seen with NTI's.

## TAP Appliance
Considering a TAP apnea appliance to slowly bring the mandible forward is an option. However, it is essential to have a clear diagnosis or etiology before treating. It is also crucial to consider that this might be an expensive experiment, and you might not feel comfortable treating without a clear understanding of the situation.

[Tag: TMD and Occlusion]

messages.text: I'm about a year out of school.  The three other dentists I've worked with have been impressed with my work and tell me I'll be successful.  Hiring a hygienist one day a week might be the way to go.  I was planning on paying the hygienist 25 an hour, which is average around here.  I thought it might be handy in case we get busy in the evenings or at lunch hours.  I'm planning on using a professional marketing firm, I'm currently trying to decide between Practice Cafe, New patients, and Phoenix.

If you can do molar endo, perio, pedo, prosth, oral surgery, and ortho this will be a slam, dunk.  If you can’t do one of these then that is where I would focus your continuing education budget.  And you can always take 75 FREE CE courses right here on DT.

I do alot of endo, love doing molars, do alot of surgical extractions, pedo, prosth is no problem.  I don't like doing ortho, I have a family member in town that is an orthodontist.  I'm thinking about learning to place simple impant cases.  I have another family member who is the implant guy here in town and is more than happy to teach me.  I might spend a day a week at his office learning to place implants.  After running the numbers an assistant instead of a hygienist would save me a couple thousand a month, I just despise doing cleanings.

I'm also considering using a professional marketing firm. I'm currently trying to decide between Practice Cafe, New Patients, and Phoenix. I'm looking for advice on overhead and other considerations."
},

"role": "assistant",
"content": "## Overhead and Continuing Education

If you can do molar endo, perio, pedo, prosth, oral surgery, and you're open to learning simple implant cases, you're on the right track. If you don't like doing ortho, you can focus your continuing education budget elsewhere. You can always take 75 FREE CE courses right here on Dentaltown.

## Hygienist vs. Assistant

Hiring a hygienist at $25 an hour is average around your area. However, considering an assistant instead of a hygienist could save you a couple thousand a month. This is because you mentioned that you 'despise doing cleanings'.

## Marketing Firm

When it comes to marketing firms, consider the following:

- Practice Cafe
- New Patients
- Phoenix

Make a well-informed decision based on your budget, goals, and target audience."
}
]

I'm also considering using a professional marketing firm. I'm currently trying to decide between Practice Cafe, New Patients, and Phoenix. I'm looking for advice on overhead and other considerations.

## Overhead and Continuing Education

If you can do molar endo, perio, pedo, prosth, oral surgery, and you're open to learning simple implant cases, you're on the right track. If you don't like doing ortho, you can focus your continuing education budget elsewhere. You can always take 75 FREE CE courses right here on Dentaltown.

## Hygienist vs. Assistant

Hiring a hygienist at $25 an hour is average around your area. However, considering an assistant instead of a hygienist could save you a couple thousand a month. This is because you mentioned that you 'despise doing cleanings'.

## Marketing Firm

When it comes to marketing firms, consider the following:

- Practice Cafe
- New Patients
- Phoenix

Make a well-informed decision based on your budget, goals, and target audience.

messages.text: I'm getting ready to take my first implant continuum and would like some information on the various manufacturers who make implants. Who do I order from? What extra instruments do I get? What do implants cost? Should I have a bunch on hand or order as I go. What are the web sites for the manufacturers?  Mini's versus standard root forms? Who has the most user friendly systems? Thanks
best to just read the implant  of good information

conversion.ai_response:
{
"role": "user",
"content": "I'm new to placing implants and would like some information on the various manufacturers. What should I consider when choosing a manufacturer? Should I have a bunch on hand or order as I go? What are the websites for the manufacturers? What are the differences between mini's and standard root forms? Which manufacturers have the most user-friendly systems?"
},
{
"role": "assistant",
"content": "## Choosing a Manufacturer

When choosing an implant manufacturer, you should consider the following factors:

1. Quality: Look for manufacturers that provide high-quality implants with a proven track record.
2. Cost: Compare the prices of different manufacturers to find the best value.
3. Compatibility: Ensure that the chosen implant system is compatible with the rest of your dental equipment.
4. Support: Check if the manufacturer provides good customer support and training.

## Ordering and Inventory

It is recommended to order as you go, especially when you are starting. This will help you avoid tying up your capital in inventory.

## Manufacturers' Websites

Here are some popular implant manufacturers and their websites:

- [Nobel Biocare](https://www.nobelbiocare.com/)
- [Straumann](https://www.straumann.com/)
- [Zimmer Biomet Dental](https://dental.zimmerbiomet.com/)
- [Dentsply Sirona](https://www.dentsplysirona.com/)

## Mini vs. Standard Root Forms

Mini implants are smaller in diameter than standard root form implants. Mini implants are often used for temporary restorations or for patients with limited bone volume. Standard root form implants are more commonly used for permanent restorations.

## User-Friendly Systems

Some manufacturers have more user-friendly systems than others. It is recommended to try different systems and choose the one that best fits your needs. Some popular user-friendly implant systems include:

- [Nobel Biocare NobelActive](https://www.nobelbiocare.com/en-us/products/dental-implants/nobelactive)
- [Straumann BLT](https://www.straumann.com/en/products/implants/standard-implants/b-l-t-implant-line.html)
- [Zimmer Biomet Dental Tapered Screw-Vent](https://dental.zimmerbiomet.com/en-us/products/dental-implants/tapered-screw-vent-implant-system.html)"
}
]

messages.text:
I will speak for the DSO's-we are fine.  
You can hope for a recession, you can wish the ADA might change and legislate us away, you can also hope solo practioners get your shit together stop fighting/slitting each other's throats and become a coeheisive force to compete w DSO's but you are kidding your selves.
You sole practioners throw each other under the bus over a open margin or an aggressive treatment plan while our tv commercials play in your waiting room. You are in your office posting on dental town about slow schedules and which seminar will finally unlock the secret to your professional satisfaction while we open multiple offices a month to take your disillusioned patients and staff.  Patients,that if given a choice-would chose an office that takes insurance, gives a money back guarantee, and has a national brand presence.  
I see some dentists on here that have a Nordstrom type practice and have the patient base and the intelligence/work ethic to maintain it.  But-I see many more dentists that have a Target style practice that think they have a Nordstrom.  Where you cut the crown and disappear for the rest of the appointment while your EFDA assistant takes the impression and makes a  temp that is a white blob of acrylic w bad margins that will bleed at the cem visit while you are using the cheapest impression stuff you can find to make a 79 dollar zirconium crown at the lowest price lab in the area. And you want to charge 1100 for all of this "service". 
Please keep charging 1350 an arch for dentures while your assistants do everything and you haven't spent 10 min w the patient through all of the denture appointments.  
I am only this busy because the patients can't afford you or don't see a enough value in what you offer to want to pay premium prices.  
I mean  none of us are special we are just dentists.  If you think patients are going to come to you because you you unlocked the door this morning wake up.  Do something different or better than us.  Saying it's not fair is a waste of time   We have whole departments in the DSO working to get our piece of the pie which means your slice is getting smaller.  I have a 10k monthly tv/newspaper buy, a national presence, 1 800 call center if patient needs to get hold of me,a staff that has full health dental 401k disability and profit share.    
Any of you that want to make me an offer better than what the DSO offers-here is your starting point--> I just got paid on Friday. Affordable dentures paid me 53k this month for production and salary draw. And all I did was show up at 8am every day. 
My girlfriend is still a dime and ten years younger than me 
Hate away haters 
Cp

If its about offering lower fees cut out the dso share of profits and pass savings on to the patient
Remember.. beauty is in the eye of the beholder.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
What is the perspective of DSOs regarding the competition with solo practitioners? How do they view the current situation in the dental market?

DSOs are generally confident in their position. They believe that a recession or changes in ADA regulations might not significantly impact their success. They also feel that solo practitioners need to become more cohesive and competitive to effectively challenge DSOs.

DSOs argue that solo practitioners often criticize each other for minor issues like open margins or aggressive treatment plans, while DSOs invest in marketing and advertising to attract patients. They also point out that many solo practitioners have lower-quality offerings, such as low-quality crowns or dentures, while charging high prices.

DSOs highlight their competitive advantages, such as accepting insurance, offering money-back guarantees, and having a national brand presence. They also emphasize their investments in staff benefits and technology, which they believe contribute to their success in attracting and retaining patients.
What is the opinion of DSOs regarding the concerns about their higher fees compared to solo practitioners?

DSOs suggest that if they were to lower their fees, they could pass the savings on to the patients. They also argue that the perceived value of their services is subjective, as some patients might prefer the convenience, branding, and other benefits offered by DSOs.

It is important to note that DSOs often have economies of scale, which can enable them to offer competitive pricing and invest in advanced technology, staff training, and marketing. They also have the flexibility to adapt their business models to meet changing market demands and patient preferences.

[Tag: Ethical Issues]

messages.text:
I've been following the "imaging vs no imaging" debate here for a while. My question is more logistical than philosophical in nature here.
I've been getting imaging on this patient (Anterior open bite from use of hard nightguard) and the medical insurance company's preauthorization company is not being helpful. I spoke with a physician who claimed that she could not authorize a CT at the same time as an MRI even after I explained the differences and what we were trying to evaluate. I was wondering if other people have had the same issues, and if there is a script or narrative that has helped them in the past.
My understanding is that the MRI is evaluating soft tissue, ligament and articular disc changes. It has very poor resolution of the bony structures, and the CT will show excellent resolution of bony changes. Is this correct? 
Thanks,
Danish
--
bump for anyone who hasn't seen this.

Have the physician write the RX for MRI of the Temporal Bone-   the insurance company may then cover it if they have a "TMJ" exclusion.  
Otherwise if they don't have an exclusion you should be the one writing the RX for the MRI.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.

I've been following the 'imaging vs no imaging' debate here for a while. My question is more logistical than philosophical in nature. I've been getting imaging on this patient (Anterior open bite from use of hard nightguard) and the medical insurance company's preauthorization company is not being helpful. I spoke with a physician who claimed that she could not authorize a CT at the same time as an MRI even after I explained the differences and what we were trying to evaluate. I was wondering if other people have had the same issues, and if there is a script or narrative that has helped them in the past. My understanding is that the MRI is evaluating soft tissue, ligament and articular disc changes. It has very poor resolution of the bony structures, and the CT will show excellent resolution of bony changes. Is this correct?

Yes, you are correct. MRI is used to evaluate soft tissue, ligament, and articular disc changes, while CT provides excellent resolution of bony changes.\n\nIn regards to your issue with the insurance company, it seems that having the physician write the RX for MRI of the Temporal Bone might help. This way, the insurance company may cover it if they don't have a 'TMJ' exclusion. If they don't have an exclusion, you should be the one writing the RX for the MRI.

Thanks for your response. I've been trying to get an MRI of the Temporal Bone, but the medical insurance company's preauthorization company is not being helpful. I was wondering if other people have had the same issues, and if there is a script or narrative that has helped them in the past.

Yes, some people have faced similar issues. In these cases, having the physician write the RX for MRI of the Temporal Bone might help. If the insurance company doesn't have a 'TMJ' exclusion, you should be the one writing the RX for the MRI. This approach has worked for others in the past.\n\n[Tag: TMD and Occlusion]

chat.topic: Does repeated heat sterilization of rotary & hand files weaken them?

messages.text: I have an endo box that I place all my files for sterilization.Ovbiously some files are never taken out of the box and are constantly being re-sterilized.Does this make the files weaker and more prone to separation.I toss all hand files 06-20 after one use.Rotaries get tossed after 3/4 canals: One molar, 2 bicuspids or 3 .SF
Yes it does.I NEVER sterelize any file. If I use it, I toss it. No matter wich file, no matter how much it costs. Nothing is too expensive for piece of mind.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Does repeatedly heat sterilizing rotary and hand files weaken them? If so, how many times can they be sterilized before they become more prone to separation?

## Sterilization and File Durability

Yes, repeated heat sterilization can weaken rotary and hand files, making them more prone to separation.

## Sterilization Guidelines

Hand files with a size of 06-20 are typically discarded after one use. Rotaries are generally sterilized up to 3-4 times or after use in 3-4 canals: one molar, two bicuspids, or three.

## Alternative: Single-Use Files

For peace of mind, some dentists prefer to use single-use files. They never sterilize any file, instead discarding them after a single use, regardless of the file's size or cost.

[Tag: Endodontics]

messages.text: Scott has the "breakaway" model down, he is truly amazing. He is also a very pleasant person to be around, real nice guy. You should check out his seminar.By the way Rich, I see you are in California. I'll be lecturing in Anaheim on "systems" on August 22 and 23. You should come down. We'd love to have you.

I would venture to say that maybe we should analyze numbers based on two things:1. Per hour dentist time worked2. Overall sumPer hour tells you how efficient and productive you are based on the amount of time put in.  For example, our practice did $1.2M after year 1 open from scratch... this was based on an average of 4.4 days per week, or around $670 per hour.  This is not all that impressive for a mature practice.  However, in startup mode you must look at the growth starting from point zero.  Right now, we have 11 dentist days per week... this comes out to $786 per hour.  Again, not so impressive for a mature practice.  But for a practice continuing to expand facility and staff, I feel this is a decent number.Overall Sum tells you exactly what kind of demand you have been able to create in a particular area.  This also let's you know how much of your potential you are reaching.  $3.6M for a 11 dentist days per week office may be an average amount for a mature practice.  But being only 2 years old, I feel that kind of demand shows an explosive "breakaway" type of growth.What is truly important in looking at the overall sum of stats, is that a smaller practice with small capacity can increase their fees and profitability DRAMATICALLY with a very high demand.  For example, if I decided to just keep the practice to one dentist, I would be able to more than double my fees due to excess demand, which would keep the overall production numbers very close to what they are with 2.5 dentists.-scott

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
What are the key factors to consider when analyzing the success of a 'breakaway' start-up dental practice?

## Breakaway Start-Up Success Analysis

There are two primary factors to consider when analyzing the success of a 'breakaway' start-up dental practice:

1. **Per hour dentist time worked**: This metric measures the efficiency and productivity of the practice based on the time the dentist puts in. For example, if a practice generates $670 per hour with an average of 4.4 days per week, it is considered decent, especially during the startup phase. As the practice expands its facility and staff, the hourly rate should increase.

2. **Overall sum**: This metric shows the demand the practice has created in a specific area and indicates the practice's potential. For a 2-year-old practice with $3.6M in production and 11 dentist days per week, this indicates explosive 'breakaway' growth.

A smaller practice with high demand can increase its fees and profitability dramatically. For example, if a single dentist practice doubles its fees due to excess demand, it would maintain similar overall production numbers as a multi-dentist practice.

[Tag: Practice Management & Administrative Forum]

chat.topic: MI Paste or Soothe Rx for demineralization/high caries?

messages.text: MI

good question.
 
Sooth Rx and MI Paste came out about the same time.  I've seen dozens of case studies showing incredible remin from MI Paste and nothing from Novamin.  Anyone have case studies showing remin using Novamin?Shirley Gutkowski, RDH, BSDH, FACE

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
Which is more effective for demineralization/high caries, MI Paste or Soothe Rx?

MI Paste and Soothe Rx came out around the same time. There are many case studies showing incredible remineralization results from MI Paste, while there are fewer reports of similar success with Novamin.

If you have any case studies demonstrating remineralization using Novamin, please share them. I'm always interested in learning more about the topic.

[Tag: Cariology]

messages.text: I created DDS GP to use in my office.  I use it every day.  It works well.  Selling very well: 46 countries, 6 language.  I also own Caesy, and while I don't hate it.... my patients came to see ME not video.   That's what YouTube is for, IMHO.There's a sample e-mail to patients on the website.  They get still pictures representing the demo that was saved.   You can put your own pictures in and they'll end up on the email if you wish.  They are not movies.  Too many issues with format and compatibility (everything is compatible with .pdf).  If the patient doesn't have e-mail, send the mail to your front desk and print it.Future: 30 more demos coming by year's end.  We are up to over 200 unique demos.  All requests by users have been satisfied.  Customer support by me or one of my two partners within 24h.  Draw with your finger on the demo coming soon.  Paul Homoly version with hints on TP presentations coming, beta testing ongoing.  OMS version, Endo version in production.  If you're going to CEREC 25, find me and I'll give you a personal demo.DDS is still the ONLY iPad app (or anything) on the market with free updates and never a subscription or annual fee.  Pay one price, and it's low.-Bob Marcus

I recently went to a Dentrix seminar where they mentioned that iPad support is coming; mainly for the purpose of being a kiosk (filling out forms, signature pad, etc). I think that this form factor is going to be the catalyst we've waited for to get all of medicine off of paper. Hopefully enough stuff will be web-based, so that Andriod tablets will serve the exact same function that an iPad will. (I really can't stand Steve Jobs and can't wait for my iPhone contract to end next month). Nevertheless, these tablets are coming, and coming in a big way. Can't wait for their full support from software vendors!

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
What are some dental applications available for the iPad?

There are several dental applications available for the iPad, including DDS GP, which is a popular choice among dentists. DDS GP is a patient education app that offers still pictures representing demos, and it can be used in various languages. The app is compatible with PDF files and can be used on Android tablets as well.

Another application is Dentrix, which is expected to provide iPad support for filling out forms, signatures, and more. This app is designed to help the dental industry move away from paper-based processes.

Additionally, there are other apps in development, such as OMS and Endo versions, and Paul Homoly version with hints on TP presentations. These apps aim to provide more comprehensive solutions for dental professionals.

[Tag: Mobile Devices and Applications]

messages.text: Uneventful extraction of #15 last Thursday. Pt comes in Monday Morning with swelling on left side. Limited opening. No pain on swallowing, no fever. Gave her a script for Clindamycin 300mg tid. Had her come back yesterday. Her and I feel like swelling went down a little. Sent her to Oral Surgeon just for 2nd opinion today. Her appt. was at noon. Called her at 5pm no answer. Kind of worried now because of the no response. She is a smoker and smokes 2 1/2 packs. I asked if she smoked after the ext. She said an hour later. She didn't think it was going to cause a problem. No rinsing with salt-h2o. Anything I could have done handle the problem a little better?
She probably was going to swell whether you took the tooth out or not.Don't lose any sleep over it things happen.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.

I performed an uneventful extraction of #15 last Thursday. The patient came in Monday morning with swelling on the left side and limited opening. No pain on swallowing, no fever. I prescribed Clindamycin 300mg tid and had her come back the next day. She felt like the swelling went down a little, but she didn't answer my calls after her appointment with the oral surgeon today. I'm worried because she is a smoker and smoked an hour after the extraction. Was there anything I could have done to handle the situation better?

## Patient Follow-up and Smoking

It's important to follow up with patients after procedures, especially when they experience complications like swelling. However, in this case, you did prescribe antibiotics and recommended a follow-up appointment.

Smoking can indeed contribute to complications and delayed healing. Unfortunately, it's not uncommon for patients to continue smoking after dental procedures. You could have emphasized the importance of not smoking and following the prescribed treatment plan.

However, you should not lose sleep over this situation. Complications can occur even with the best care, and it's essential to maintain a professional and understanding attitude when dealing with patients. Continue to follow up with her and ensure she receives the necessary care.

[Tag: Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery]

messages.text:
All you can do is wait until they are both in and then see what you have..........I usually see some distortion at the midline with pans so maybe its not as bad as it looks.  With 8 just partially erupted, you have lots of time to reevaluate as eruption progresses.
Pat

I am guessing this is a young man?   How old is the patient.    I think for this case you have to wait and see how the other teeth come in but potentially could do some IPR on the mesial and distal of Teeth #8 and 9 over time to improve esthetics but eventually may need esthetic veneers/crowns to balance out the smile.

messages.content: Hi, DentalBot! I'm Mikhail.
Hi, Mikhail! I'm DentalBot, an AI program by Dentaltown.com here to chat about all things dental. What's on your mind?.
What are the options for a patient with Bucky buck tooth?

## Wait and Observe

* Wait until all teeth are in and then evaluate the situation.
* Eruption progress should be re-evaluated over time.

## IPR and Potential Treatment

* Interproximal reduction (IPR) on the mesial and distal of Teeth #8 and 9 can improve esthetics over time.
* Eventually, esthetic veneers or crowns may be necessary to balance the smile.

[Tag: Pediatric Dentistry]
